summary: This document is an email chain from July 2020 between FBI forensic examiners and US Attorney's Office prosecutors regarding the status of processing digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the US Virgin Islands. It details the challenges in extracting, organizing, and transferring terabytes of data from numerous devices for discovery purposes.

persons.name: Steve
persons.role: FBI NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: Primary FBI forensic examiner communicating with the US Attorney's Office about the status of processing digital evidence from Epstein searches. Provides detailed updates on device processing and data transfer.

persons.name: Mandy
persons.context: Prosecutor from the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) coordinating with the FBI to receive processed evidence from the Epstein searches. Expresses urgency and clarifies requirements.

connections.description: Working relationship between FBI forensic examiner and prosecutor to process and transfer digital evidence for the Epstein case. Involves technical coordination and status updates.

events.title: Evidence Processing Status Update
events.description: Email update from FBI forensic examiner Steve detailing that 2 iPhones and 3 iPads have been processed with reports generated, 1 iPad is at HQ for unlocking, 28 items have been imaged, and 11 items are ready for review.

events.title: Follow-up on USVI Materials
events.description: Prosecutor Mandy follows up on the estimated timeline for receiving all evidence materials from the US Virgin Islands searches.

events.title: Updated Device Descriptions Provided
events.description: Steve provides an updated list of seized device descriptions to the US Attorney's Office, including electronically reported serial numbers for thumb drives and SD cards.

events.title: Prosecutor Outlines Major Data Review Problems
events.description: Mandy sends a detailed email outlining significant problems with previously received data, including inability to link emails to attachments, lack of native file links in the load file, and mismatched control numbers, rendering over a million documents difficult to review.

locations: US Virgin Islands (USVI) - Epstein's island property
keyFacts: The FBI had processed terabytes of digital evidence from searches of Epstein's New York and US Virgin Islands properties, including computers, servers, phones, tablets, and loose media.
Significant technical and organizational challenges plagued the evidence review, including an inability to link emails to their attachments in the forensic data provided to prosecutors.
Prosecutors were urgently seeking a complete, searchable set of evidence to pursue possible additional charges and meet discovery obligations to defense counsel.
The email chain reveals the massive scale of the digital seizure, with one device alone containing over 500,000 emails.
Coordination was complicated by the COVID-19 pandemic, with examiners working reduced schedules and prosecutors working from home.
